Award.AbstractNarration:
This research studies the impact of racial status on gatekeeper-client relations. Gatekeepers control access to "benefits" they do not own, benefits that are valued by "clients." Seeking access to those benefits, clients assume obligations which may be discharged by a fee paid to the gatekeeper. Employment agents, car salesmen, real estate agents are gatekeepers because they control access to jobs, cars and housing respectively as well as information about each. When clients are lower status, for example African American, employment agents may steer them to lower paid, less desirable jobs, car salesmen may ask for and receive higher prices, and real estate agents may show only segregated housing. This research will experimentally test the impact of racial status differences on gatekeeping. Do African American gatekeepers gain smaller fees from White clients? What happens when Whites are gatekeepers? Do African American clients pay higher fees for the access they seek? And what is the impact of the race of the person to whom clients seek access? These questions are important for both practical and theoretical reasons. The research findings will help us better understand the continuing effects of status differences and stratification on everyday life.

Multiracial gatekeeping is studied in the context of exchange networks. For example, B is the gatekeeper when an A - B exchange must be completed before A may exchange with C. B is the gatekeeper because A, acting in the role of client, must gain B's consent to exchange before gaining access to and exchanging with C. As a part of the research, a measure of the quantitative impact of race differences is developed, along with hypotheses drawn from that measure. The research uses a 2 x 2 x 2 (race of A, race of B, race of C) design to test hypotheses. Funded by the Digital Library Initiative at the National Science Foundation, ExNet will be used to produce exchange relations among actors. Subjects seated in separate rooms negotiate through connected PCs using only mouse control. ExNet shows the network being investigated as an active display on each subject's screen. Subjects click icons to make and reject offers and to complete exchanges.

Broader Impacts

Findings will advance understandings of discriminatory practices in which power over racial minorities is grounded jointly in structure and status. Formal sociological theory is extended through new bridges between Network Exchange Theory and Status Characteristics Theory; perhaps the most extensively tested formal theories in sociology. More generally, results of will show how racially grounded status differences affect access to commodities that people value, potentially shedding light on one of the systemic, structural ways in which discrimination persists. While the research focuses on the impact of race on gatekeeping, the underlying theoretical process is not limited to racial status. It applies to any gatekeeping setting where "status characteristic" (identifiable attribute of individuals that carries with it cultural beliefs and/or evaluations of worthiness and competence) becomes salient. Gender, age, beauty and sexual orientation, for example, are all status characteristics, and when they become salient in a gatekeeper-client relationship, their effects should be the same as those predicted for racial status.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research summarized here investigated the impact of racial status on gatekeeping in laboratory experiments. Gatekeepers control access to ‘benefits’ they do not own, benefits that are valued by ‘clients’ (Corra 2000; Corra and Willer 2002). Seeking access to those benefits, clients assume obligations which may be discharged by a fee paid to the gatekeeper. Employment agents, car salesmen, real estate agents are gatekeepers because they control access to jobs, cars and housing respectively as well as information about each. When clients are lower status, for example African American, employment agents may steer them to lower paid, less desirable jobs, car salesmen may ask for and receive higher prices, and real estate agents may show only segregated housing.

More specifically, the project experimentally investigated how differences in the racial statuses of gatekeepers and clients affect the gatekeeper-client relationship in order to answer several research questions, including: does race-based status diminish the power of Black gatekeepers of White clients and does race-based status enhance the power of White gatekeepers over Black clients? Multiracial (Black-White) gatekeeping is studied in the well-understood context of exchange networks (See accompanying Figure). Previous research by Corra and Willer (2002) demonstrated that fees of gatekeepers like A are determined by the value of the access granted to clients like B. The study summarized here extends that analysis by asking whether, for a given access, the gatekeeper’s fee varies with the racial status of gatekeeper and client.

Experiments show that racial status does indeed deflate the power of Black gatekeepers of White clients, and significantly so. In fact, findings of this study show that the power of Black gatekeepers of White clients is completely eliminated. Black gatekeepers virtually “settled” for equipower (even division) exchange ratios.

On the other hand, while race-based status did enhance White’s exercise of gatekeeping power over Blacks, the effect was small, much smaller than might have been expected from well-documented field research. That is to say, very frequently those of lower racial status have been shown to pay more. Sometimes this effect seemed to be due to gatekeeping: for example where black women were quoted substantially higher auto prices than white males. However, Blacks also pay more for food but they do so because of opportunity costs. When the supermarkets available to Blacks are few, they need not offer competitive prices.

More broadly, the research summarized here sought to provide answers to a recurring question in the sociological literature: Have the traditional status effects of race declined such that blacks now are mainly or wholly disadvantaged by power grounded in current structures as maintained by some? (E.g., Wilson 1980, 1989). Or do the status effects of race grounded in the past work alongside current structural power to doubly disadvantage blacks as asserted by others? (See Ridgeway 2014 for a recent statement). Importantly, this controversy can be resolved and the study summarized here is a step in that direction. Because it is an experimental investigation, the effects of power due to structure and of influence due to status can be separated and are separated with study result. For gatekeeping, a power relation, I show that the power of low status (Black) gatekeepers is countervailed by influence and, for high status (White) gatekeepers, I show that power and influence work together to the disadvantage of the low status (Black) client. More generally, when this research and field studies are taken together, there is no doubt that, not just gatekeeping, but gatekeeping together with other race-related conditions act to disadvantage Blacks.

Finally, while the work summarized here focused on the impact of race on gatekeeping, theory tested should be widely applicable across an array of social relations and structures. The underlying theoretical process outlined is not limited to racial status. It should apply to any gatekeeping setting where any status characteristic becomes salient (Corra 2014).  Gender, occupation, beauty and sexual orientation, for example, are all “status characteristics” (identifiable attributes of individuals that carry with them cultural beliefs and/or evaluations of worthiness and competence)(Webster and Driskell 1983; Webster and Hysom 1998; Webster, Hysom and Fullmer 1998; Ridgeway et al. 2009), and when they become salient in a gatekeeper-client relationship, their effects should be the same as those for racial status.

In conclusion, the goal of the project summarized here was to advance understandings of processes of inequality in which power over racial minorities is grounded jointly in structure and status. To mention only one result of this study, that low status gatekeepers of high status clients do not exercise power, appears to be a new contribution and one that highlights an advantage of experimental study. To my knowledge, there is no field research on how Black gatekeepers of White clients fare, undoubtedly because of the limited number of Black gatekeepers in the field.
